docs.snippet: What's a gin and tonic without the clink of ice cubes? But a glass of white or rosé wine is another matter. When the wine is not quite chilled, you could do what French chefs do: drop in an ice cube, leave it for a minute or two, then scoop it ou...
docs.abstract: Comment on some tips for ice to cool wine without diluting it; photo (S)0
docs.lead_paragraph: What's a gin and tonic without the clink of ice cubes? But a glass of white or rosé wine is another matter. When the wine is not quite chilled, you could do what French chefs do: drop in an ice cube, leave it for a minute or two, then scoop it out.

headline.main: Ice That Won't Water the Wine

docs.snippet: Arabica from Tanzania is the cabernet of coffee: a dark, rich brew with an aroma that hints of raisins and is balanced with good acidity. That describes the dark roast coffee from Sweet Unity Farms, a cooperative community in southern Tanzania tha...
docs.lead_paragraph: Arabica from Tanzania is the cabernet of coffee: a dark, rich brew with an aroma that hints of raisins and is balanced with good acidity. That describes the dark roast coffee from Sweet Unity Farms, a cooperative community in southern Tanzania that was started about 20 years ago by David Robinson, who settled in Tanzania. Mr. Robinson is a son of Jackie Robinson, the baseball player. A 12-ounce bag, caffeinated only, ground or whole bean, is $8 at Garden of Eden in Manhattan and Brooklyn, Jerry's Red Horse Market in East Hampton, N.Y., or from www.sweetunityfarms.com.

headline.main: From Tanzania, a Rich Start to the Morning

docs.snippet: Field-grown mâche is unlike most mâche, or lamb's lettuce, that is sold in produce markets. Usually, mâche is grown hydroponically, that is, not in soil but in nutrient-enhanced liquid, and is softer, leggier and less flavorful than mâche grow...
docs.abstract: Field-grown mache is now available in several New York City markets; photo (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: Field-grown mâche is unlike most mâche, or lamb's lettuce, that is sold in produce markets. Usually, mâche is grown hydroponically, that is, not in soil but in nutrient-enhanced liquid, and is softer, leggier and less flavorful than mâche grown in the alluvial earth near Salinas, Calif., by Epic Roots. Clusters of field-grown mâche are sweet, but with a mineral assertiveness and enough texture to stand up to dressing. It's a year-round crop, and is sold in four-ounce bags for $5.99 at Citarella and Dean & DeLuca stores, and $4.99 at Agata & Valentina and Gourmet Garage.

headline.main: Lettuce With Roots Firmly in the Earth

docs.snippet: Many Chinese dishes cook in minutes, but the trimming, chopping, seasoning and marinating you have to do beforehand can take considerable time. For those seeking shortcuts, Deluxe Food Market, 79 Elizabeth Street (Hester Street), sells seasoned an...
docs.abstract: Deluxe Food Market in Chinatown sells trimmed, seasoned and marinated meat, poultry and seafood ready for quick cooking at home; photo (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: Many Chinese dishes cook in minutes, but the trimming, chopping, seasoning and marinating you have to do beforehand can take considerable time. For those seeking shortcuts, Deluxe Food Market, 79 Elizabeth Street (Hester Street), sells seasoned and marinated meat, poultry and seafood, right, that is ready for the steamer or wok. It's the newest and largest of a chain of Chinatown markets. Marinated rib-eye, spareribs with black beans, chicken with mushrooms, ground pork with preserved vegetables, sole with garlic and ginger, sea bass with black beans and marinated frogs' legs are just a few of the dozens of choices. Most are $2.29 to $5.99 a pound, and yield extremely tasty results. Pigs' ears and tripe, which are complicated to clean and trim, are also available, seasoned and ready to cook. The store also sells fresh, unmarinated but well-trimmed meat, some vegetables and condiments, and prepared dishes like roast chickens ($6 each), pork buns and dumplings, and offers hot prepared dishes at $2.75 a portion. There is also a bakery and sushi counter. Everything is clearly labeled in English as well as in Chinese.

headline.main: Trimmed, Marinated and Ready for the Wok

docs.snippet: With a table like this, who would use a tablecloth? It is one of a kind, an Art Deco design by Lee Weitzman of Chicago, made in Canada of curly maple, with black and mother-of-pearl accents. The table seats six at Atelier, the restaurant in the ne...
docs.abstract: Atelier, in new Ritz-Carlton Hotel on Central Park South, is latest restaurant to feature bare table as fashion statment; its one-of-a-kind Art Deco table made of curly maple, with black and mother-of-pearl accents, was designed by Lee Weitzman; photo (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: With a table like this, who would use a tablecloth? It is one of a kind, an Art Deco design by Lee Weitzman of Chicago, made in Canada of curly maple, with black and mother-of-pearl accents. The table seats six at Atelier, the restaurant in the new Ritz-Carlton on Central Park South. ''We wanted this table to be the focus of the room, the power table,'' said Ronan Henaff, the manager of Atelier, which opens on Saturday. Tables without cloths are a fashion statement at some high-end restaurants. The Zenlike Kai uses only slate place mats. Shiny lacquer tabletops are bare at Opia. And Industry (Food) shows off its polished wood.

headline.main: You'll Never Find This Table Airing Dirty Linen

docs.snippet: Stick one of these new Italian kitchen scales on the roof of your car and you could stop traffic -- all it needs is a siren. Made by Guzzini, the scale gives you a choice of pounds or grams, with a maximum of two kilograms or four and a half pound...
docs.abstract: Guzzini of Italy designs kitchen scale; photo (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: Stick one of these new Italian kitchen scales on the roof of your car and you could stop traffic -- all it needs is a siren. Made by Guzzini, the scale gives you a choice of pounds or grams, with a maximum of two kilograms or four and a half pounds. You can easily set it to zero by turning the bottom. It can be used with or without a rimmed receptacle on top. The scale comes in red or silver and will be available by the end of the week for $50 at Dean & DeLuca stores.

headline.main: Weighing Potatoes or Pasta In Grams or Ounces

docs.snippet: Canadian bacon, usually smoked and ready to eat, is something entirely different in Canada. North of the border, it is brined, rolled in cornmeal and sold uncooked. A juicy meat with a sweet, nutty flavor hinting of cloves and a light saltiness, i...
docs.abstract: Canadian bacon can now be ordered over Internet; drawing (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: Canadian bacon, usually smoked and ready to eat, is something entirely different in Canada. North of the border, it is brined, rolled in cornmeal and sold uncooked. A juicy meat with a sweet, nutty flavor hinting of cloves and a light saltiness, it makes a delicious sandwich and will certainly ennoble eggs Benedict. Real Canadian Bacon -- a brand name -- is sold in slices for a quick sizzle in a pan, or ready to roast in two-and-a-half and five-pound sizes. About 20 minutes a pound at 325 degrees for the smaller size and 15 minutes a pound for the larger is all it takes for extremely succulent results. The coating is called pea meal, because crushed dried yellow peas were originally used to make it, and the name stuck.

headline.main: O Canada! Do Pass the Bacon!

docs.snippet: High-end London restaurants serve sticky toffee pudding, a dark, dense, cakelike confection, which is a specialty of the Lake District of northwest England. One brand, from the English Pudding Company, is also sold in the food halls at Fortnum & M...
docs.abstract: British sticky toffee pudding, once province of high-end London restaurants, is available now in New York; photo (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: High-end London restaurants serve sticky toffee pudding, a dark, dense, cakelike confection, which is a specialty of the Lake District of northwest England. One brand, from the English Pudding Company, is also sold in the food halls at Fortnum & Mason and Harvey Nichols. Three years ago, Simon Johns, whose family started the company, moved to Los Angeles and opened a branch there. His Sticky Toffee Pudding has now made it to New York, where it is sold, frozen, for $10.50 (to serve six) at Dean & DeLuca. The pudding is served warm, and the 18-ounce container can be heated in a conventional or microwave oven. It can be ordered online for $13 plus shipping from www.stickytoffeepudding.com.

headline.main: It's Very British, It's Very Sticky, And It's Over Here

docs.snippet: When Gary Ibsen, a tomato grower in Carmel, Calif., asked Julia Child what kind of heirloom tomato she would like to bear her name, she said, ''A tasty one, my dear.'' After experimenting, he selected an organic beefsteak to be called the Julia Ch...
docs.abstract: Gary Ibsen, tomato grower in Carmel, Calif, selects organic beefsteak tomato to be called the Julia Child; drawing (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: When Gary Ibsen, a tomato grower in Carmel, Calif., asked Julia Child what kind of heirloom tomato she would like to bear her name, she said, ''A tasty one, my dear.'' After experimenting, he selected an organic beefsteak to be called the Julia Child. The seeds are $4.50 a pack from www.tomatofest.com, with 30 cents going to the American Institute of Wine and Food, which Mrs. Child helped found.

headline.main: This Beefsteak Tomato Has a Lofty Calling

docs.snippet: Some pepper mills do yeoman work in the kitchen, and some are designed for the table. In the meant-to-be-seen category, there are dozens of giftworthy vintage examples at Deco Deluxe, 993 Lexington Avenue (72nd Street). Some are handsome, in silve...
docs.abstract: Deco Deluxe sells elegant vintage pepper mills; photo (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: Some pepper mills do yeoman work in the kitchen, and some are designed for the table. In the meant-to-be-seen category, there are dozens of giftworthy vintage examples at Deco Deluxe, 993 Lexington Avenue (72nd Street). Some are handsome, in silver or pewter. Others are amusing, resembling a Champagne cork or a monk. One, from Christofle, was made of ebony and ivory. All are in good working order. They range from $100 to $500 each. Some mills have matching salt shakers. The shop also specializes in vintage cocktail gadgets, another gift idea.
